content: As reported this morning on NBC News, the Republican Party has garnered its lowest public approval rating -- 26% -- ever historically. The Democratic Party registered a 48% approval rating in the same poll. At this time, there is a 68% approval rating for Mr. Obama peronally and a 60% approval rating for his six-week performance as president. An interview with Michael Steele, chairman of the RNC, focused on the current "leadership debate" within Republican ranks, notably between Steele and Rush Limbaugh. Steele was politically evasive in avoiding any direct answers regarding this week's "rhubarb" between the two other than Steele admitting that he did not handle the situation well. It appears to me that Limbaugh has deftly filled a leadership vacuum in the Republican ranks following the devastating presidential and Congressional losses in November and given that he has an established, loyal radio audience that is frustrated by the lack of any effective Republican counterstrategy to the Democrats (Just say "no" amply sums it up) or any inspiring party leadership. Given his perch as a talk show host without any meaningful responsibilities beyond his daily broadcasting, Limbaugh has effectively emasculated an already faltering and stumbling Republican leadership. In his attacks on both the Obama administration and the Republican leadership, Limbaugh has ably splintered what little unity remained in the Republican ranks after last fall's elections. It's very easy to be destructive; let's see if Limbaugh is capable of genuine political "heavy lifting" -- providing appealing and constructive alternative strategies to the Democratic platform well in place now. With his characteristic self-centered approach and focus on his favorite person -- himself -- and life long avoidance of any meaningful contributions beyond himself, it seems that Limbaugh would be a more worthy successor to continue Sigmund Freud's personality studies (id, ego, superego) than qualified for actual political work needed in the Republican Party.

content: The disarray within the Republican senate ranks is pretty clear. When Senator McCain proposed an amendment (SA 592) to the Omnibus Bill (HR 1105) that essentially stripped the pork out of it, the amendment was opposed by 63, supported by 32. Nine Republicans opposed it and two didn't take a position (Not Voting). Among them were my two, one a "NAY" vote and one an "NV". I expressed my disappointment to them this morning by e-mail and telephone. If Republicans are going to take a principled stand in the press, then they had better take a principled stand in what they add to a bill ... and how they vote. While I can't see my way to finding a home in the Democratic camp, I am increasingly finding the Republican camp an uncomfortable place to be as well. The old saw "actions speak louder than words" comes to mind ... and the words are loud but the actions weak.

content: As reported this morning on NBC News, the Republican Party has garnered its lowest public approval rating -- 26% -- ever historically. The Democratic Party registered a 48% approval rating in the same poll. At this time, there is a 68% approval rating for Mr. Obama peronally and a 60% approval rating for his six-week performance as president. An interview with Michael Steele, chairman of the RNC, focused on the current "leadership debate" within Republican ranks, notably between Steele and Rush Limbaugh. Steele was politically evasive in avoiding any direct answers regarding this week's "rhubarb" between the two other than Steele admitting that he did not handle the situation well. It appears to me that Limbaugh has deftly filled a leadership vacuum in the Republican ranks following the devastating presidential and Congressional losses in November and given that he has an established, loyal radio audience that is frustrated by the lack of any effective Republican counterstrategy to the Democrats (Just say "no" amply sums it up) or any inspiring party leadership. Given his perch as a talk show host without any meaningful responsibilities beyond his daily broadcasting, Limbaugh has effectively emasculated an already faltering and stumbling Republican leadership. In his attacks on both the Obama administration and the Republican leadership, Limbaugh has ably splintered what little unity remained in the Republican ranks after last fall's elections. It's very easy to be destructive; let's see if Limbaugh is capable of genuine political "heavy lifting" -- providing appealing and constructive alternative strategies to the Democratic platform well in place now. With his characteristic self-centered approach and focus on his favorite person -- himself -- and life long avoidance of any meaningful contributions beyond himself, it seems that Limbaugh would be a more worthy successor to continue Sigmund Freud's personality studies (id, ego, superego) than qualified for actual political work needed in the Republican Party.

content: The disarray within the Republican senate ranks is pretty clear. When Senator McCain proposed an amendment (SA 592) to the Omnibus Bill (HR 1105) that essentially stripped the pork out of it, the amendment was opposed by 63, supported by 32. Nine Republicans opposed it and two didn't take a position (Not Voting). Among them were my two, one a "NAY" vote and one an "NV". I expressed my disappointment to them this morning by e-mail and telephone. If Republicans are going to take a principled stand in the press, then they had better take a principled stand in what they add to a bill ... and how they vote. While I can't see my way to finding a home in the Democratic camp, I am increasingly finding the Republican camp an uncomfortable place to be as well. The old saw "actions speak louder than words" comes to mind ... and the words are loud but the actions weak.

content: As reported this morning on NBC News, the Republican Party has garnered its lowest public approval rating -- 26% -- ever historically. The Democratic Party registered a 48% approval rating in the same poll. At this time, there is a 68% approval rating for Mr. Obama peronally and a 60% approval rating for his six-week performance as president. An interview with Michael Steele, chairman of the RNC, focused on the current "leadership debate" within Republican ranks, notably between Steele and Rush Limbaugh. Steele was politically evasive in avoiding any direct answers regarding this week's "rhubarb" between the two other than Steele admitting that he did not handle the situation well. It appears to me that Limbaugh has deftly filled a leadership vacuum in the Republican ranks following the devastating presidential and Congressional losses in November and given that he has an established, loyal radio audience that is frustrated by the lack of any effective Republican counterstrategy to the Democrats (Just say "no" amply sums it up) or any inspiring party leadership. Given his perch as a talk show host without any meaningful responsibilities beyond his daily broadcasting, Limbaugh has effectively emasculated an already faltering and stumbling Republican leadership. In his attacks on both the Obama administration and the Republican leadership, Limbaugh has ably splintered what little unity remained in the Republican ranks after last fall's elections. It's very easy to be destructive; let's see if Limbaugh is capable of genuine political "heavy lifting" -- providing appealing and constructive alternative strategies to the Democratic platform well in place now. With his characteristic self-centered approach and focus on his favorite person -- himself -- and life long avoidance of any meaningful contributions beyond himself, it seems that Limbaugh would be a more worthy successor to continue Sigmund Freud's personality studies (id, ego, superego) than qualified for actual political work needed in the Republican Party.

content: The disarray within the Republican senate ranks is pretty clear. When Senator McCain proposed an amendment (SA 592) to the Omnibus Bill (HR 1105) that essentially stripped the pork out of it, the amendment was opposed by 63, supported by 32. Nine Republicans opposed it and two didn't take a position (Not Voting). Among them were my two, one a "NAY" vote and one an "NV". I expressed my disappointment to them this morning by e-mail and telephone. If Republicans are going to take a principled stand in the press, then they had better take a principled stand in what they add to a bill ... and how they vote. While I can't see my way to finding a home in the Democratic camp, I am increasingly finding the Republican camp an uncomfortable place to be as well. The old saw "actions speak louder than words" comes to mind ... and the words are loud but the actions weak.
